title: Plenty of Fun and Adventure for the Inner Child
content: Castle in the Sky is a film directed by Hayao Miyazaki. What a fun thrill ride this was. Floating castles. Sky pirates. Gorgeous visuals. Jaw-dropping action. Fun humor. Add all these together and it makes one of my favorite animated films ever.Where should even I start with this masterpiece? Well, first the story. It's just a basic coming-of-age, adventure story. Two kids, Pazu and Sheeta, find a mysterious object, so together they try to discover the secret behind this object as well as learn more about each other. Throw in some bad guys here and there, and you got yourself an adventure film fun for the whole family.But of course, that isn't enough from the great Miyazaki. I'm sure any other filmmaker would have done a fine job with this premise. Miyazaki, however, gives his audience an engaging story with such a grand and epic fantasy experience. He puts so much effort into this film, I felt as if I was coming along for the ride. I would have loved to have seen this film on the big screen. Watching the cinematic opening scene and hearing the beautiful theme song. When I first watched it, I felt I was gonna like it. I didn't expect to love it so much!I saw the English dubbed version, which I always prefer for anime. Though, I think the dub could have been a little better. The main problem were the two main characters. It's fine as it is, but I think Pazu sounded older than he looked. Also Sheeta has what I believe was a British accent throughout the film, but her accent would sometimes sound like it was fading in and out. With all that said, if anyone reading this prefer subtitles with the original audio, that's fine too. It's understandable.Another thing I should point out is not really a complaint, just an observation. The pacing does slow down towards the end. It's not a problem, but it also wouldn't be a problem if about 5 minutes were shaved off. But, it still helps set the mood and atmosphere. Those who haven't seen the movie should keep in mind that it isn't all fast-paced action.Overall, I really love this movie. A film like this can only be topped by Miyazaki's own "My Neighbor Totoro" (but that's for another review). I highly recommend it for the whole family. And if you get the chance, check out the incredible soundtrack. I can honestly say this is one of my favorite films ever.

title: The Brothers Grimm of our days go by the names of Hayao Miyazaki & Studio Ghibli
content: Wow, another ride on a roller-coaster, created by Studio Ghibli and its personal saint, Hayao Miyazaki. I still don't know what impressed me more about it: The art, the pictures or the fantasy the story is driven by. I probably never will be able to make a decision about that.So forget about that and let me just say, watching a movie that carries the name "Miyazaki" somewhere is a guarantee for being on a trip through fantastic lands, inhabited by fresh, cool, amusing, impressive creatures and enjoying some of the most charming and unpredictable tales ever told.Some words on the graphics: This movie was made in a time where a computer that was capable of displaying the game "Pong" in a decent way had the size of a one-story-house. There was no Pixar, no ILM, no WETA Digital. There were crayons, pens and the talented hands of the incredible crew, gathered around Hayao Miyazaki. And just with that they created animated pictures that even nowadays let most other cartoons look like the work of an infant. An example? Just take a look at the castle towards the end.This is not a movie. This is a world on its own. And I enjoyed the visit.I can't wait till Christmas because this piece of art is gonna be one of my presents. Two more words: Special Edition!

title: Even in Their Early Works, Studio Ghibli Fires on All Cylinders
content: Airships, floating islands, sky pirates and lost civilizations in this dreamy, upbeat animated adventure. It's the first-ever film produced by Studio Ghibli and only Hayao Miyazaki's second feature-length (after 1984's Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind), but already both parties are testing their boundaries and nonchalantly blowing past expectations. Really incredible that Laputa still stands up so well, given its age and scope, and I mean that in both an artistic and a thematic sense.There's a rich sense of humanity to the plot and a sweet innocence shared by the determined young protagonists (both Miyazaki hallmarks), with an irresistible fiber of discovery running through the whole production. And, naturally, each of the fantastical flying machines and techno-organic wonders are fleshed out to an absurd level, with operational mechanics playing a crucial role in several memorable scenes. That's another Miyazaki calling card, for those keeping track at home.Meanwhile, the animation team swiftly meets and defies convention in a series of brilliant, preposterous early action scenes. Most remarkable among these is a crazy automotive chase through a sleepy mining village and across an active railroad bridge, an intensely kinetic effort that's bursting with creative power and realized potential. Ghibli can do the pulse-pounding stuff extremely well, right out of the gates, but the team also knows how to let a delicate moment linger, to give a scene room to breathe for greater dramatic effect. Those latter points are important during the climax, as we explore a crumbling airborne palace and learn about the forgotten culture it once housed. All this, of course, while dodging the military and foiling the efforts of a particularly formidable evil mastermind (voiced, in the English dub, by Mark Hammill).Despite the years, Laputa is timeless; a magical, warm-hearted fantasy ride that deserves equal footing with many of the studio's later, more heralded works. It might even be more impressive than Mononoke or Spirited Away, considering the team's relative inexperience at the time.

title: A Beautiful and Timeless Miyazaki Film
content: Personal Rating: 9/10I last watched this movie when I was nine years old. Nine years later, I revisited it and fell in love with the same enchanting storytelling I did so many years ago.Hayao Miyazaki is a master at his craft, creating a universe that lives on the edge of realism and idealism that captivates you. The visuals are stunning, it's impossible to compare them to the likes of Disney and Pixar because it's just so different, it's as if every frame could be a piece in an art museum. Coupled with an enchanting story, likable characters (even though some were quite shallow), fantastic pacing, and an incredible score by Joe Hisaishi. This is a movie you should go ahead and buy because you can watch it over and over again without it ever getting old.Okay, I have to go on about the score, it's beautiful. It was the music that brought back so many memories for me of when I watched this movie as a child. It was the music that had stuck with me all these years. Joe Hisaishi creates feelings not just sounds.The Girl Who Fell From The Sky - Joe Hisaishi

title: Unveiling the Enchantment: Exploring the Wonders of 'Castle in the Sky'
content: In the realm of animated masterpieces, "Castle in the Sky" stands tall as a testament to the unparalleled creativity and imagination of Studio Ghibli. Directed by the visionary Hayao Miyazaki, this enchanting film weaves a mesmerizing tapestry of adventure, wonder, and timeless charm. From the very first frame, viewers are transported to a world unlike any other, where floating cities and mythical civilizations exist amidst the clouds. The animation is nothing short of breathtaking, with every scene meticulously crafted to perfection. At the heart of the story are the unforgettable characters, each with their own dreams, aspirations, and inner struggles. Sheeta, a courageous young girl with a mysterious past, finds herself embarking on a perilous journey after encountering the brave and determined Pazu. Together, they set out to uncover the secrets of Laputa, a legendary kingdom hidden among the clouds. As their adventure unfolds, Sheeta and Pazu encounter a cast of colorful characters, from sky pirates and government agents to ancient robots and mystical creatures. Along the way, they discover the true power of friendship, courage, and the human spirit. One of the most remarkable aspects of "Castle in the Sky" is its ability to resonate with audiences of all ages. While children will be enthralled by the thrilling action and fantastical elements, adults will appreciate the film's deeper themes and universal messages. The music, composed by the legendary Joe Hisaishi, is the perfect accompaniment to the stunning visuals, elevating every moment with its haunting melodies and sweeping orchestral score. In conclusion, "Castle in the Sky" is a timeless masterpiece that continues to inspire and enchant audiences around the world. Its rich storytelling, breathtaking animation, and unforgettable characters make it a true gem of the animated genre. Whether you're a longtime fan or discovering it for the first time, this film is sure to leave a lasting impression that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

title: Better than Spirited Away
content: In no way am I slamming Spirited Away! It is a great film! But there is something about the purity of Castle in the Sky that blows me away. Has there ever been a more beautiful title sequence than the one in this film or a more beautiful musical theme or a more breathtaking castle? Each scene seems patiently thought through and carefully timed. The character development is plentiful but not overdone. I really love this film. More than anything else, I think it is dear to my heart.For one thing, I can't get over the action sequences. The mother is hilarious and totally runs the show with her band of hyper-masculinized idiots. It is a real joy to see the cars swerve back and forth as characters speed down the road in a tense car chase. There is real humor and grit in this film, and I believe that it belongs on anyone's list of classics, along with the rest of Ghibli's repertoire.My introduction to this film was upon reading Leonard Maltin's movie guide book about 7 years ago. I was very surprised to see that he had given a Japanese anime film 4 stars. (If anyone is familiar with Maltin, you would know he doesn't just "give away" four stars). He said that it was one of the best action films ever made, animated or otherwise. I was already familiar with Miyazaki's work via Spirited Away and was very excited to get my hands on a copy of Castle in the Sky. At first, I wasn't all that impressed with the film. It seemed melancholy compared to the flat-out dynamism of Spirited Away. But over time this film has warmed up to me and has earned a special place on my shelf. I would recommend to anyone interested in seeing this film, or who has seen it before and didn't really like it, to give it time. Allow Castle in the Sky to enchant you. It is SO worth it.

title: Originally seen without a dub, but I understood everything
content: This film was pushed on me by a anime hound as his favorite movie. I watched it, undubbed and no subtitles, and it became one of my own favorite films. I don't hearing the actual dialog for the first helped. Via the images, I already knew it, somehow. And what fantastic imagery -- some of the best imagery I've seen in any film. There is indeed a Castle in the Sky, from which one may rule.Highly recommended.

title: A film to watch when you're young, and watch again when you've grown up
content: Like many reviewers here, I also recommend to watch it in the original Japanese. Characters are more vivid, and the music is more atmospheric. Unfortunately, Disney was too true to its policy not to allow a moment without music when nobody is talking. Miyazaki's (or a characteristic to any Japanese artwork) mastery of sound and silence, existence and voidness, were thereby systematically destroyed. It's also noticeable that music was grossly modified. Some may like this way, but I believe the original held the beauty of this film more effectively. Simply, my ears remember it as I heard in the original even though it was more than 10 years ago!The dubbing was done alright. Mark Hamill ('Muska') and Cloris Leachman ('Dola') were excellent. But James van der Beek ('Pazu') was a wrong choice. Pazu is good-natured, but essentially a tough orphan boy who works in a mine. Van der Beek cannot act on such a role, and instead he made Pazu sound like a middle-class boy who would perform well at school. Pazu in the original was a boy who wouldn't look back a second, but Pazu van der Beek was a rich boy who tried to be wild and that was pathetic.Is there a lesson in this film, besides entertainment? Many say it's about power and greed. Sure, those are important sidelines. But I think the most important message was the critique on our industrial civilisation. Towards the end of the film, Sheeta says "I see now why the Laputians left the castle. You cannot live away from the earth and soil!" I reckon this is the one-line message from Miyazaki. During the opening credit, we see the concise history of the Laputa world: a steam engine -> industrial revolution -> advances to the sky -> flying cities -> arms race -> war -> people leaving from the fallen ships -> back to the simple life on earth. Miyazaki's world view is clear - he's an environmentalist. He also has a social side. In planning this film, Miyazaki travelled to Wales. It was 1980s, when many mining towns were suffering from closure. Miyazaki felt so much compassion to those townspeople, and made those people immortal in this film. Though idealised, we meet them in Pazu's mining valley.

title: Don't bother with Avatar when this is avaiable

title: Yet another Miyazaki masterpiece (surprise).
content: It almost sounds demeaning to call this one of the most enjoyable animated films I've ever seen; it is, in fact, one of the most enjoyable films of any kind I've ever seen.  Anyone familiar with the work of Miyazaki will find a lot of familiar territory here: the rural setting, the preoccupation with aircraft, the mythic themes. What separates this (along with the hilarious "Porco Rosso") is its playful brand of movie-serial cliffhanger action. There's much more to smile at here than in its more serious cousins such as Mononoke and Nausicaa. It's one of the handful of films that one can point to when trying to demonstrate the heights of which animation is capable.

title: Masterpiece of Animation and Storytelling
content: "Castle in the Sky" is not just a film; it's an experience that encapsulates the very essence of what makes Studio Ghibli a timeless treasure in the world of animation. The beautiful animation, with its breathtaking landscapes and intricately designed characters, serves as the perfect canvas for a story that resonates deeply with the human spirit.The tale is a profound exploration of innocence corrupted by the greed of men, and how the purity of children and the beauty of nature can be tainted by this insatiable desire for power. Watching Pazu and Sheeta's journey, I felt an overwhelming sense of wonder and a desire to be a better person. Their bravery, kindness, and unwavering hope in the face of adversity remind us of the purity and strength that lies within each of us.The story is more than just an adventure; it's a poignant commentary on the impact of human greed on the world around us. The contrast between the lush, vibrant world of Laputa and the desolate, mechanical reality below highlights the consequences of our actions on the environment and our communities.Adding to the film's magic is the soul-capturing score by Joe Hisaishi. His music perfectly complements the narrative, enhancing every emotional beat and drawing viewers even deeper into the world of Laputa. The hauntingly beautiful melodies linger long after the movie ends, encapsulating the film's themes of wonder, innocence, and the bittersweet passage of time."Castle in the Sky" is a film that stays with you long after the credits roll. It inspires reflection and a renewed sense of responsibility towards the world we live in. It's a reminder that, despite the darkness in the world, there is always hope and the potential for redemption.This film is a masterpiece, deserving of a perfect score. It beautifully blends stunning animation with a story that is both heartwarming and thought-provoking. "Castle in the Sky" is a testament to the power of storytelling and its ability to inspire us to be better, kinder, and more mindful of the world and people around us.

title: A beautiful and magical adventure movie
content: Many people who have never seen anime consider it all one genre. This movie proves this wrong more effectively  than any other one I've seen. Laputa: castle In The Sky is magical, funny, sweet and wonderfully animated. A young boy, Pazu, catches a girl falling from the sky, a glowing stone on a necklace she wears. From there, the two are chased by the army and pirates, all trying to find the beautiful and powerful floating castle of Laputa. Not only is Laputa a wonderful adventure story, it can make you stop and think about the horrible effects of war and absolute power. I very nearly cried at the end. Try and see the original subtitled version, though I haven't seen the new dub, with the original music and voices.

title: Why not just tune into Nickelodeon?
content: I had ordered this film with much anticipation off the Internet, since I had already seen most of Miyazaki's works, and I was surprised that it didn't grab me at all. The animation is very simple, it looks exactly like any Saturday morning cartoon (although admittedly, some of the backgrounds are of a higher caliber). The only things to differentiate it from a programme on Nickelodeon are the magical and beautiful score by Hisaishi, and the storyline. I would've loved to love this movie as much as I did Miyazaki's other efforts, but it just didn't have any resonance, it was too cartoony and childish. Maybe I'll watch it again and gain a different impression, maybe I've been spoiled by Spirited and Mononoke, but I just know this isn't anywhere near as impressive as those.4/10

title: I LOVE THIS FILM!!!
content: I first saw this film when I was five and I have loved it ever since. It has to be my all time favourite in the world - and I've seen a lot more films than most people so I'm a tough critic!
